title: 105_s1642
content:
The Act is titled the "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1998". It includes findings related to financial assistance management. The Congress finds that there are over 600 different Federal financial assistance programs, some of which have duplicative or burdensome administrative requirements, hindering cost-effective service delivery at the local level. State, local, and tribal governments, along with nonprofit organizations, are facing complex problems that require coordinated services. Streamlining and simplification of Federal financial assistance administrative procedures and reporting requirements will improve service delivery to the public. The purposes of this Act are to improve the effectiveness and performance of Federal financial assistance programs, simplify application and reporting requirements, enhance service delivery to the public, and promote greater coordination among service providers. In this Act, the term "Director" refers to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, "Federal agency" means any agency defined under section 551(1) of title 5, United States Code, and "Federal financial assistance" has the same meaning as defined in section 7501(a)(5) of title 31, United States Code. The term "nonprofit organization" refers to any organization operated primarily for scientific, educational, service, charitable, or similar purposes in the public interest. A nonprofit organization operates for public interest, not primarily for profit, using proceeds to maintain or expand operations. The term "State" includes various entities within the United States and its territories. The term "tribal government" refers to an Indian tribe as defined in section 7501(a)(9) of title 31, United States Code. "Uniform administrative rule" is a government-wide rule for achieving national policy objectives across multiple Federal financial assistance programs. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. Federal agencies must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act's enactment. The plan should streamline procedures for financial assistance programs, participate in interagency processes, use a common application system, and designate a lead agency official. The agency's responsibilities under the Act include allowing electronic applications for funds, ensuring timely and high-quality reporting from recipients of financial assistance, and setting annual goals to measure performance. The agency must comply with the Government Performance and Results Act, and if unable to do so, the Director must report to the Senate and House committees. The Director may extend the plan development period for noncompliant agencies for up to 12 months. Each agency must publish the plan developed. Each agency must publish the plan developed under subsection (a) in the Federal Register for public comment through various means, including public forums. The lead official designated under subsection (a)(4) must consult with non-Federal entities during plan development and implementation, including representatives of State, local, and tribal governments. Each Federal agency must submit a plan to the Director and Congress, reporting annually on its implementation and performance in meeting specified goals. The report may be included in general management reports required by law. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and non-Federal entities, shall direct and assist Federal agencies in establishing a common application and reporting system for Federal financial assistance programs. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and non-Federal entities, shall establish a common system for applying, managing, and reporting on funding from multiple Federal assistance programs. This system will have uniform administrative rules across different Federal agencies. An interagency process will address ways to streamline and simplify Federal programs. The Director will establish a common system for managing funding from multiple Federal assistance programs, with uniform administrative rules. This includes streamlining administrative procedures, improving coordination of information sharing, and enhancing the quality of information received by Federal agencies from recipients of Federal financial assistance. The Director may designate a lead agency and use interagency working groups to assist in implementing the responsibilities under this Act. Agencies must submit information for review regarding their implementation of the Act. The Director has the authority to exempt Federal agencies or programs if deemed necessary. The Director may exempt Federal agencies from certain responsibilities if they do not have many Federal financial assistance programs. Exempted agencies will be listed on OMB's website. SEC. 7. EVALUATION. The Director shall contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act. The evaluation, to be submitted within 4 years, will assess the Act's effectiveness and provide recommendations for further implementation. The Director will evaluate agency performance in achieving goals, assess coordination among federal, state, local, and tribal entities in implementing the Act. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF INFORMATION.

Federal agencies can gather necessary information for reviewing the financial integrity of activities receiving Federal financial assistance.

SEC. 9. JUDICIAL REVIEW.

There is no judicial review of compliance with the Act, and no provisions create enforceable rights through administrative or judicial actions.

SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS. SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS.

This Act does not override statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET.

The Act will be effective upon enactment and will expire five years later.
